Posts.Content: Hi Cathy - I am now 41 and was diagnosed w/ breast cancer in 2000 at age 35,(Stage 11), on 1/30/06, after I was expecting and "all clear", I was devasted to learn that the cancer had spread to my liver and bone. I have a wonderful doc that is nothing but positive. I'm being treated w/ Abraxane (family to taxol) and Avastin. This regiment started in Aug 2006 and my liver counts are within normal and my tumor markers are within 20 points of normal Originally, my tumor markers were in the high 200's and have dropped after 8 treatments to 51. Normal being 31<. My doctor and I are hopeful and he is a big supporter of Avastin... I am also on Zumeta for bone strenthening 1x per month. Good luck with your mother.
Posts.Title: Avastin For Br. Cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Alicia - Sounds like my story - in 2000, age 35, i was diagnosed w/ Stage II, no nodes involved. Fast forward to 2006 age 40, wasdiagnozed with Breast Mets to bone and liver. I'm having a hard time coping, because when I feel good, I think i over do it and pay the next couple of days. It's very frustrating and like you, want my life to return to normal or at least know when that might happen. I guess we have to remember that the treatment is brutal and that is what makes life difficult. Once treatment has put cancer in remission, we can hope that we'll start healing and feeling better each day....keep the faith and stay informed, everyone has something to share and it may or may not work for you. Whatever oncologist you see, I recommend a good nutritionalist. What you eat, how you eat can make a difference. All my best to you.. Beth
Posts.Title: Living With Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: On 2/11/2008 cacann wrote: I was diagnosised with Breast Cancer late November 2007.  I had two back to back surgeries with the placement of the port during the last surgery as we knew I was going to have chemo treatments.  I did not start the chemo until the middle of January, but was already having problems with the port.  The area felt sore and bruised, and when I would turn a certain way, it felt like a pin was sticking into my skin.  I mentioned to my Occologist doctor the port does not feel right.  He looked at it, and stated it is just a vial in a vial.   I did not ask any more questions as the removal of the port would be worse as the veins in my arms are impossible to get.  Some of the cancer nurses have had problems connecting the IV's to the port.  One nurse said the port was wobbly.    Is this pain normal?  The pain is tolerable and does not hurt all the time.  I notice it mostly at night.   I've had a port for over 2 years for Stage IV Met Breast Cancer - I've never experienced what you're talking about - sometimes it's a little sore or slightly bruised right after treatment - but that's it.  Are the nurses getting a good return of blood when the access?
Posts.Title: port installed hurts
